mn22:0.2: The Simile of the Venomous Snake
mn22:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn22:2.1: Now at that time a bhikkhu called Ariṭṭha, who had previously been a vulture trapper, had the following harmful view:
mn22:2.2: “As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, the acts that he says are obstructions are not really obstructions for the one who performs them.”
mn22:3.1: They went up to Ariṭṭha and said to him,
mn22:3.2: “Is it really true, Friend Ariṭṭha, that you have such a harmful view:
mn22:3.3: ‘As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, the acts that he says are obstructions are not really obstructions for the one who performs them’?”
mn22:3.4: “Absolutely, friends. As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, the acts that he says are obstructions are not really obstructions for the one who performs them.”
mn22:3.5: Then, wishing to dissuade Ariṭṭha from his view, the bhikkhus pursued, pressed, and grilled him,
mn22:3.6: “Don’t say that, Ariṭṭha! Don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for misrepresentation of the Buddha is not good. And the Buddha would not say that.
mn22:3.7: In many ways the Buddha has said that obstructive acts are obstructive, and that they really do obstruct the one who performs them.
mn22:3.8: The Buddha says that sensuality give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and the danger in them is what's greater.
mn22:3.9: With the similes of a skeleton …
mn22:3.16: a butcher’s knife and chopping block …
mn22:3.18: a snake’s head, the Buddha says that sensuality give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and the danger in them is what's greater.”
mn22:3.19: But even though the bhikkhus pursued, pressed, and grilled him in this way, Ariṭṭha obstinately stuck to his view and insisted on stating it.
mn22:3.20: When they weren’t able to dissuade Ariṭṭha from his view, the bhikkhus went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
mn22:5.1: So the Buddha addressed one of the bhikkhus,
mn22:5.2: “Please, bhikkhu, in my name tell the bhikkhu Ariṭṭha, formerly a vulture trapper, that
mn22:5.4: “Yes, Bhante,” that bhikkhu replied. He went to Ariṭṭha and said to him,
mn22:5.6: “Yes, friend,” Ariṭṭha replied. He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,
mn22:5.7: “Is it really true, Ariṭṭha, that you have such a harmful view:
mn22:5.8: ‘As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, the acts that he says are obstructions are not really obstructions for the one who performs them’?”
mn22:5.9: “Absolutely, Bhante. As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, the acts that he says are obstructions are not really obstructions for the one who performs them.”
mn22:6.1: “Useless man, who on earth have you ever known me to teach the Dhamma in that way?
mn22:6.2: Haven’t I said in many ways that obstructive acts are obstructive, and that they really do obstruct the one who performs them?
mn22:6.3: I’ve said that sensuality give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and the danger in them is what's greater.
mn22:6.4: With the similes of a skeleton …
mn22:6.11: a butcher’s knife and chopping block …
mn22:6.13: a snake’s head, I’ve said that sensuality give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and the danger in them is what's greater.
mn22:6.14: But still you misrepresent me by your wrong grasp, harm yourself, and create much demerit.
mn22:6.15: This will be for your lasting harm and suffering.”
mn22:7.1: Then the Buddha said to the bhikkhus,
mn22:7.3: Is this bhikkhu Ariṭṭha even warmed up in this teaching and training?”
mn22:7.6: When this was said, Ariṭṭha sat silent, dismayed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say.
mn22:7.8: “Useless man, you will be known by your own harmful view.
mn22:7.9: I’ll question the bhikkhus about this.”
mn22:8.1: Then the Buddha said to the bhikkhus,
mn22:8.2: “Bhikkhus, do you understand my teaching as Ariṭṭha does, when he misrepresents me by his own wrong grasp, harms himself, and creates much demerit?”
mn22:8.4: For in many ways the Buddha has told us that obstructive acts are obstructive, and that they really do obstruct the one who performs them.
mn22:8.6: The Buddha has said that sensuality give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and the danger in them is what's greater.
mn22:8.7: With the similes of a skeleton …
mn22:8.8: a snake’s head, the Buddha has said that sensuality give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and the danger in them is what's greater.”
mn22:8.9: “Good, good, bhikkhus! It’s good that you understand my teaching like this.
mn22:8.10: For in many ways I have said that obstructive acts are obstructive …
mn22:8.13: I’ve said that sensuality give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and the danger in them is what's greater.
mn22:8.14: But still this Ariṭṭha misrepresents me by his wrong grasp, harms himself, and creates much demerit.
mn22:8.15: This will be for his lasting harm and suffering.
mn22:9.1: Truly, bhikkhus, it is quite impossible to engage in sensual acts without sense desire, and without perceptions and thoughts of sensuality.
mn22:10.1: Take a foolish person who memorizes the teaching—
mn22:10.2: statements, mixed prose & verse, discussions, verses, inspired exclamations, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and elaborations.
mn22:10.3: But they don’t consider the meaning of those teachings with understanding,
mn22:10.4: and so don’t come to a considered acceptance of them.
mn22:10.5: They memorize the teaching for the sake of finding fault and winning debates.
mn22:10.6: They don’t realize the goal for which they memorized them.
mn22:10.7: Because they’re wrongly grasped, those teachings lead to their lasting harm and suffering.
mn22:10.9: Because of their wrong grasp of the teachings.
mn22:10.10: Suppose there was a person in need of a venomous snake. And while wandering in search of a venomous snake
mn22:10.11: they’d see a big venomous snake,
mn22:10.12: and grasp it by the coil or the tail.
mn22:10.13: But that venomous snake would twist back and bite them on the hand or the arm or limb,
mn22:10.14: resulting in death or deadly pain.
mn22:10.16: Because of their wrong grasp of the venomous snake.
mn22:10.17: In the same way, a foolish person memorizes the teaching …
mn22:10.23: and those teachings lead to their lasting harm and suffering.
mn22:10.25: Because of their wrong grasp of the teachings.
mn22:11.1: Now, take a gentleman who memorizes the teaching—
mn22:11.2: statements, mixed prose & verse, discussions, verses, inspired exclamations, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and elaborations.
mn22:11.3: And once he’s memorized them, he considers their meaning with understanding,
mn22:11.4: and comes to a considered acceptance of them.
mn22:11.5: He doesn’t memorize the teaching for the sake of finding fault and winning debates.
mn22:11.6: He realizes the goal for which he memorized them.
mn22:11.7: Because they’re correctly grasped, those teachings lead to his lasting welfare and happiness.
mn22:11.9: Because of his correct grasp of the teachings.
mn22:11.10: Suppose there was a person in need of a venomous snake. And while wandering in search of a venomous snake
mn22:11.11: they’d see a big venomous snake,
mn22:11.12: and hold it down carefully with a cleft stick.
mn22:11.13: Only then would they correctly grasp it by the neck.
mn22:11.14: And even though that venomous snake might wrap its coils around that person’s hand or arm or some other limb, that wouldn’t result in death or deadly pain.
mn22:11.16: Because of their correct grasp of the venomous snake.
mn22:11.17: In the same way, respectable gentlemen memorize the teaching …
mn22:11.23: and those teachings lead to their lasting welfare and happiness.
mn22:11.25: Because of their correct grasp of the teachings.
mn22:12.1: So, bhikkhus, when you understand what I’ve said, you should remember it accordingly.
mn22:12.2: But if I’ve said anything that you don’t understand, you should ask me about it, or some competent bhikkhus.
mn22:13.1: Bhikkhus, I will teach you a simile of the Dhamma as a raft: for crossing over, not for holding on.
mn22:13.2: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
mn22:13.5: “Suppose there was a person traveling along the road.
mn22:13.6: They’d see a large body of water, whose near shore was dubious and perilous, while the far shore was a sanctuary free of peril.
mn22:13.7: But there was no ferryboat or bridge for crossing over.
mn22:13.11: ‘Why don’t I gather grass, sticks, branches, and leaves and make a raft? Riding on the raft, and paddling with my hands and feet, I can safely reach the far shore.’
mn22:13.12: And so they’d do exactly that.
mn22:13.13: And when they’d crossed over to the far shore, they’d think,
mn22:13.14: ‘This raft has been very helpful to me.
mn22:13.15: Riding on the raft, and paddling with my hands and feet, I have safely crossed over to the far shore.
mn22:13.16: Why don’t I hoist it on my head or pick it up on my shoulder and go wherever I want?’
mn22:13.18: Would that person be doing what should be done with that raft?”
mn22:13.20: “And what, bhikkhus, should that person do with the raft?
mn22:13.21: When they’d crossed over they should think,
mn22:13.22: ‘This raft has been very helpful to me. …
mn22:13.24: Why don’t I beach it on dry land or set it adrift on the water and go wherever I want?’
mn22:13.25: That’s what that person should do with the raft.
mn22:13.26: In the same way, the Dhamma has been taught by me similar to a raft: for crossing over, not for holding on.
mn22:14.1: By understanding the simile of the raft, you will even give up the teachings, let alone what is against the teachings.
mn22:15.1: Bhikkhus, there are these six grounds for views.
mn22:15.3: Take an untrained ordinary person who has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen true persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the true persons.
mn22:15.4: They regard form as: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’

mn22:15.9: And as for this ground for views:
mn22:15.10: ‘The world and the self are one and the same. After death I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, imperishable, and will last forever and ever.’

mn22:16.2: They regard form like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

mn22:18.1: When he said this, one of the bhikkhus asked the Buddha,
mn22:18.2: “Sir, can there be anxiety about what isn't there externally?”
mn22:18.5: ‘Oh, it once was mine but is mine no more.

mn22:18.7: They sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

mn22:19.1: “But can there be no anxiety about what isn’t there externally?”
mn22:19.4: ‘Oh, it once was mine but is mine no more.
mn22:19.5: Oh, it could be mine but I do not get it.’
mn22:19.6: They don’t sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.
mn22:19.7: That’s how there is no anxiety about what isn’t there externally.”
mn22:20.1: “But can there be anxiety about what isn’t there internally?”
mn22:20.3: “It’s when someone has such a view:
mn22:20.4: ‘The world and the self are one and the same. After death I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, imperishable, and will last forever and ever.’
mn22:20.5: They hear the Realized One or their disciple teaching Dhamma for the uprooting of all grounds for views, standpoints, obsessions, insistences, and underlying tendencies; for the pacification of all activities, the letting go of all appropriation, the ending of craving, dispassion, cessation, Nibbāna.
mn22:20.7: ‘I’m going to be annihilated and destroyed! I won’t even exist any more!’
mn22:20.8: They sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.
mn22:20.9: That’s how there is anxiety about what isn’t there internally.”
mn22:21.1: “But can there be no anxiety about what isn’t there internally?”
mn22:21.3: “It’s when someone doesn’t have such a view:
mn22:21.4: ‘The world and the self are one and the same. After death I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, imperishable, and will last forever and ever.’
mn22:21.5: They hear the Realized One or their disciple teaching Dhamma for the uprooting of all grounds for views, standpoints, obsessions, insistences, and underlying tendencies; for the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all appropriation, the ending of craving, dispassion, cessation, Nibbāna.
mn22:21.7: ‘I’m going to be annihilated and destroyed! I won’t even exist any more!’
mn22:21.8: They don’t sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.
mn22:21.9: That’s how there is no anxiety about what isn’t there internally.

mn22:28.1: Seeing this, a trained noble disciple grows disenchanted with form, feeling, perception, activities, and consciousness.
mn22:29.1: Being disenchanted, he’s dispassionate. With dispassion, he’s freed. When he’s freed, he knows he’s freed.
mn22:29.2: He understands: ‘Birth is exhausted, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there will be no more of this.’
mn22:30.1: Such a bhikkhu is one who is called ‘one who has lifted the cross-bar’, ‘one who has filled in the moat’, ‘one who has pulled up the pillar’, ‘one who is unbarred’, and also ‘a noble one with banner lowered and burden dropped, detached’.
mn22:31.1: And how has a bhikkhu raised the cross-bar?
mn22:31.2: It’s when a bhikkhu has given up ignorance, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
mn22:31.3: That’s how a bhikkhu has lifted the cross-bar.
mn22:32.1: And how has a bhikkhu filled in the moat?
mn22:32.2: It’s when a bhikkhu has given up the transmigration through births involving renewed being, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
mn22:32.3: That’s how a bhikkhu has filled in the moat.
mn22:33.1: And how has a bhikkhu pulled up the pillar?
mn22:33.2: It’s when a bhikkhu has given up craving, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
mn22:33.3: That’s how a bhikkhu has pulled up the pillar.
mn22:34.1: And how is a bhikkhu unbarred?
mn22:34.2: It’s when a bhikkhu has given up the five lower fetters, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them, so they’re unable to arise in the future.
mn22:34.3: That’s how a bhikkhu is unbarred.
mn22:35.1: And how is a bhikkhu a noble one with banner lowered and burden dropped, detached?
mn22:35.2: It’s when a bhikkhu has given up the conceit ‘I am’, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
mn22:35.3: That’s how a bhikkhu is a noble one with banner lowered and burden dropped, detached.
mn22:36.1: When a bhikkhu’s mind was freed like this, the gods together with Indra, Brahmā, and the Progenitor, search as they may, will not find:

mn22:37.1: Though I state and assert this, certain ascetics and brahmins misrepresent me with the false, hollow, lying, untruthful claim:
mn22:37.2: ‘The ascetic Gotama is an exterminator. He advocates the annihilation, eradication, and obliteration of a being that exists.’
mn22:37.3: I have been falsely misrepresented as what I am not, and saying what I do not say.
mn22:37.5: In the past, as today, what I describe is suffering and the cessation of suffering.
mn22:37.6: This being so, if others abuse, attack, harass, and trouble the Realized One, he doesn’t get resentful, bitter, and emotionally exasperated.
mn22:38.1: Or if others honor, respect, revere, or venerate him, he doesn’t get thrilled, elated, and emotionally excited.
mn22:38.2: If they praise him, he just thinks,
mn22:38.3: ‘Such acts are done to me regarding that which was completely understood beforehand.’
mn22:39.1: So, bhikkhus, if others abuse, attack, harass, and trouble you, don’t make yourselves resentful, bitter, and emotionally exasperated.
mn22:39.2: Or if others honor, respect, revere, or venerate you, don’t make yourselves thrilled, elated, and emotionally excited.
mn22:39.3: If they praise you, just think,
mn22:39.4: ‘Such acts are done to me regarding that which was completely understood beforehand.’

mn22:42.1: Thus the teaching has been well explained by me, made clear, opened, illuminated, and stripped of patchwork.
mn22:42.2: In this teaching, there are bhikkhus who are Arahants, who have exhausted the influxes, completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own goal, utterly exhausted the fetters of being, and are rightly freed through enlightenment. For them, there is no round of existence to be found. …
mn22:43.2: In this teaching, there are bhikkhus who have given up the five lower fetters. All of them reappear spontaneously. They are extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world. …
mn22:44.2: In this teaching, there are bhikkhus who, having given up three fetters, and weakened passion, aversion, and muddledness, are once-returners. All of them come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering. …
mn22:45.2: In this teaching, there are bhikkhus who have given up the three fetters. All of them are stream-enterers, not liable to the underworld, bound for awakening. …
mn22:46.2: In this teaching, there are bhikkhus who are Dhamma-followers or faith-followers. All of them are bound for awakening.
mn22:47.1: Thus the teaching has been well explained by me, made clear, opened, illuminated, and stripped of patchwork.
mn22:47.2: In this teaching, there are those who have a degree of faith and fondness for me. All of them are bound for heaven.”
mn22:47.3: That is what the Buddha said.
mn22:47.4: Satisfied, the bhikkhus delighted in what the Buddha said.
